results.notes: Lawn not far from old growth oak; white pine and spruce in the vicinity.

These are the “mystery red mouths” in last year’s Observation 249571. They are found at the exact same location and basically the exact same time (August 29 instead of August 25).

They come a neighbor’s lawn in between several mature oaks, a hemlock, and a maple. It is a myco-rich area where I have found at least 5-10 different bolete species and at least 20 others. “Classic oak-subvelutipes” were found at the same time, including a single specimen from about 5-10 feet away. The others differ from that one in many material ways. [I will add that photo at the end – look for the caption]

We last had rain about a week ago but the ground is far from dry.

Mycelium was white. Cap ranged from dark red to brown. I know from last year that they end up a very dark brown. A few of the younger caps had notable velvet on top, but not all. More mature specimens were flat on top with rounded pores, while younger specimens were flat underneath with a rounded cap.

The pores on younger specimens are a dark orange-red but not the same crimson I see in the “oak subvelutipes” nor the brownish orange in our vermiculo-somethings. Both these and the oak-types regularly have a yellow edge on the pores, while the vermiculo-somethings do not. These get much more orange with age, at least partly because the pores are opening and thereby spreading the red shade out. The pores go truly brown as the specimens get older.

Specimens covered all ages, though I left the rotting ones behind. Context was a little marshmallow-y compared to the oak-types I find. Interesting Note: The temperature thing continues to bear out. The oak-types were colder to the touch even an hour or two later when I examined them all at home.

There is a strong but not overpowering mushroom smell. I know that the older ones develop a powerful, almost overwhelming odor so bad that the owner hates to mow them.

In last year’s observation I emphasized the odd staining pattern. Quoting:

“The most striking feature is the staining of the context. The underlying, pre-stained context is creamy yellow (the photos seem whiter than they look in life). When cut the stipe very rapidly stained a bright red, while the cap slowly and indifferently stained toward blue…”

Later finds confirmed that the cherry red began in the base and worked its way up as the mushroom ages.

These were a bit younger but the pattern continues. The flesh stains bluish green rather than the dark blue I associate with the oak-types, and much slower. Older specimens also display an ever-growing cherry red in the stipe context, beginning at the base and working upward.

Stipe colors varied from mostly yellow, to a brownish tan, to more red, to one oddball that was entirely reddish-brown. By contrast, the oak-type specimen displays a bright-yellow stipe with occasional red, and is much more sensitive to bruising.

Chemical tests were all indifferent and hard to read. I did them with the drop-and-dab method that clears away extra liquid with a clean q-tip. All tests go ammonia, KOH, and then FeSO4 from left to right. Separate photos were taken on a specimen with the red base in order to see how the different parts of the flesh would react. NOTE: There are two photos of that final photo. The lighter one has an increased “exposure” setting.

HEIGHT: 7 cm (last year 9.5 cm)
CAP WIDTH: 7.5 cm(last year 10 cm)

TUBES: 1 cm (last year 3.75 cm)

Selected for the indicated MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection № MF54424.
More than one collection brought back from the NJMA foray and displayed on the ID tables. I grouped them together at the foray, assuming they were all the same entity; indeed, the thumbnail pic shows 7 fruitbodies that look like a single species based on the macro-morphology. However, the 2nd fruitbody on right happened to be different, as its context stained only pale pinkish-red, not blue like the rest! I will post that single basidiocarp separately as L. scabrum. The remaining 6 fbs are likely the same mushroom seen in obs 281644 and possibly in obs 287648.

Growing in sandy soil in need duff under pitch pines along the Red Trail and near a small pond/bog in the middle of nowhere. There were no mature oaks in this area, just a couple of scrub oaks saplings, which makes me think this mushroom is likely to be mycorrhizal with the pines. This spot is a new collection site for this fairly rare mushroom, located ~800 m to the SSW of the location where obs 102459 & obs 179586 were made.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous 1130 bps TEF-1 sequence was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. The sequence starts from the first character following the EF1-983F primer (primer edited out). The sequence is 585 bps long through to and including the EF1-1567R primer (thus, a total of 608 bps with the forward primer). There are no ambiguous characters, it’s a single haplotype.
> A BLASTn of the first 585 characters (the most commonly sequenced region) gave a profile consistent with this organism belonging to a unique lineage in the Boletaceae. The top hit at 97% is Boletus aff. mcrobbii HKAS 56280 (#KF112265). Following this, the similarity immediately drops to 90%.
> A phylogenetic tree was built in GenBank and attached to this post with my annotations. It consists of ~50 hits that happen to be taxa belonging in the genera currently assigned to the dustbin called “Pulveroboletus Group” (in the parlance of Wu et al. 2014, 2016), i.e. the clades that don’t fit into the 6 recognized phylogenetic subfamilies.1,2 These hits were chosen based on the observed clustering pattern favoring these clades and excluding hits that happen to reside in the named subfamilies. Inclusion of taxa in Pulveroboletus was necessary in light of the results of Wu et al. (2014, 2016), Smith et al. (2015) and Zeng et al. (2017) showing that Xerocomus aff. mcrobbii (=Clade 43 in Wu et al.) is a sister clade to Pulveroboletus with the bootstrap support of >90%. 3,4.
> Boletus weberi is a member of a unique lineage (genus) in the Boletaceae that hasn’t been formally described yet. The ‘Boletus weberi complex’ mentioned in Ortiz-Santana et al. (2007) consists of weberi itself and B. rubropictus (North America) and B. guatemalensis (Mesoamerica).5 Boletus granulopunctatus (Japan) and Xerocomus mcrobbii (New Zealand, see Dr. Halling’s obs 204748) appear to be related morphologically. The whole morpho-clade has a unique gestalt look about it.
References:
1 Wu et al., “Molecular phylogenetic analyses redefine sever major clades and reveal 22 new generic clades in the fungal family Boletaceae”, Fungal Diversity 2014, term 69(2), pp.93-115
2 Wu et al., “One hundred noteworthy boletes from China”, Fungal Diversity 2016, term 81, pp. 25–188
3 Smith et al., "New sequestrate fungi from Guyana: Jimtrappea guyanensis gen. sp. nov., Castellanea pakaraimophila gen. sp. nov., and Costatisporus cyanescens gen. sp. nov. (Boletaceae, Boletales), IMA Fungus 2015, term 6(2), pp. 297–317
4 Zeng et al., “The genus Pulveroboletus (Boletaceae, Boletales) in China”, Mycologia 2017, term 109(3), pp. 1-21
5 Ortiz-Santana et al., “Boletes from Belize and the Dominican Republic”, Fungal Diversity 2007, term 27, pp. 247-416 (see p. 305)

Growing in grass under mature pitch pines and young scrub oaks.
The medium-brown cap is pulvinate-convex, 7 cm across and 1.5 cm thick in the middle. The pore surface is whitish to pale cream, bruising brown. The tubes are 8-9 mm deep, bruising brown. The slightly bent yellow-brown, densely granulose-punctate and tapering downward stipe is 5 cm long, 2.3 cm wide in the apex, 2 cm wide in the middle and 1.7 cm wide near the base. The context is white, hyaline-marbled in the stipe, slowly staining brownish. The odor is slight and unpleasant. The taste is mild at first, then slightly bitter. KOH on cap = dark brown.
The collection site is only 15-20 yards away from where obs 288807 was collected one week later.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 12-Sep-23):
A full-length consensus nrITS sequence of 480 bps was derived from this collection by Dr. Kudzma from two clean reads. There is a single ambiguity (R = A/G) at the 11th position from the start of the locus (the 5’ end).
A BLASTn-100 of this sequence gave two 99.6% similar hits from collections made in Florida and labeled as Tylopilus balloui (MH016791 & MH211983), which I think were misidentifed. Following these hits, the % similarity drops to 97-98% (2 hits) and then down to ~92%, with lower query covers and E values above zero.
I got curious if there are bona fide accessions of B. balloui and conducted separate BLASTn search specifically targeting T. balloui. It appears that there are none, as the additional 15 hits recovered from this search are all from either China or Japan. Apparently no one has bothered to sequence balloui from the USA probably because it’s such an easy to identify bolete.
While I have collected a more typical -looking T. balloui in the Pine Barrens (e.g. obs 74480 and obs 477940), the present collection, IMO, represents a different taxon. Compare with the presumably pine-associated obs 245958, also from the NJ Pinelands.
I have recently submitted the classic oak-associated T. balloui from an upland deciduous forest of northern NJ for sequencing, obs 426868, so hopefully we’ll get a verdict soon. I suspect we may have a species group of two or more taxa, some of which can be separated on the basis of ecology.

results.notes:
A group of several specimens growing in moss under a large maple in a grove of white oaks just a few yards from obs 288112.
The largest specimen with a 9 cm wide cap was picked and preserved. The copious white milk didn’t change color even after 15 min; upon drying it stained the gills pinkish brown. The flesh was mild (tasted for at least 2 min) and didn’t have an odor when crushed. The gills and spore print were pale ochraceous. With this information in hand, I successfully keyed it out to couplet 33a (lignyotus) in Eastern Field Key Group B in Milk Mushrooms of North America by Bessettte-Roody-Bessette.
However, after seeing lots of bona fide L. lignyotus at the NJMA foray in Stokes State Forest a week later, this collection has a different “feel” to it. In addition, the cap margins in this collection were not plicate and only slightly sulcate, and the globose to broadly ellipsoid spores were in the 7-9.5 μm range (though the warts were thick and 1-1.5 μm long and the wide-mesh partial reticulum was very prominent, which is consistent with lignyotus).
DNA results results and discussion (posted on 9-Jan-22; updated on 10-Apr-23):
My original ID from morphology as “Lactarius lignyotus group” appears to be supported by BLASTn results. This collection, however, is not Lactarius lignyotus in the strict (European) sense. For starters, the ecology (Pine Barrens) and host tree (oaks) are not a match for lignyotus s.s.
The ITS sequence blasts to seven GenBank accessions with 99.3-100% similarity, two of which came from Florida (MH211756 and MH211868), likely from the same coastal plain habitat). The Massachusetts accession from AFTOL labeled as “Lactarius lignyotus”, DQ221107, is a misidentification. The more recent accessions from Indiana material are by Steve Russell (as “sp. ‘lignyotus-IN01’”: OP642998, OP643042 & OP643132) and from New York state (ON179792). The true L. lignyotus accessions from Europe are only 94-95% similar.
For a nice account of the lignyotus complex in North America, see https://www.mushroomexpert.com/lactarius_lignyotus.html.

results.notes:
Caps about 3 mm, found under the same log as the asco in Observation 288963. Growing from grass stems, one of which appeared alive.

Basidia 2-spored, 18+3 x 5. Spores 8-10 × 2.5-3. No reactions in Melzer’s. No hymenial cystidia. Caulocystidia ~40 × 5.

H. ignobilis lacks cystidia but has smaller spore length/width ratio (2 vs. 3 here) and larger, 4-spored basidia. Measurements are OK for H. epichloe, which has been found both 2- and 4-spored. The uncommon habitat (leaves and stems of grasses) is just right for this species. Inflated hymenophoral cells are also mentioned. Under diverticulate pileipellis hyphae, we have a layer of inflated cells like in Mycena, and this is a noticeable difference from the drawing in Antonin & Noordeloos, where these cells are shown as cylindrical. There is a possible issue with the gills: they are typically reduced in H. epichloe and here we see them well developed. Finally, H. epichloe is a European species, I don’t know if there are any records from other parts. All in all, I wouldn’t bet more than 50c that this collection represents a true H. epichloe — it’s just the best name I can attach to it.

results.notes:
A single mature fruitbody growing in leaf litter in sandy soil in a grove of young white oaks. The collection site is just yards away from where B. bicolor of obs 73634 & obs 208545 and ‘Xerocomus’ sclerotiorum of obs 288112 have been found.

Description:
> The cap is plano-convex, 7.8 cm wide and 2 cm thick in the middle, pale yellow-cream in the disk and pale rose-pink elsewhere; surface bald and leathery in the disk and scruffy-granulose elsewhere (texture visualized well with a lens); the cap margin is devoid of a sterile flap; the cap flesh is light yellow, moist and mashmallowy, staining blue slightly and erratically/spotty at the junction with the stipe and occasionally above the tubes.
> The pores are yellow, large, angular and compound, i.e., honeycombed when looking into the tubes, bluing when injured. The tubes are 8 mm deep in the thickest section, concolorous with the pore surface and bluing upon injury.
> The shallowly S-shaped stipe is 10.5 cm long, flaring to 2 cm at the junction with the cap and of uniform width of 1.1 cm below the apex down to the base, lemon yellow at the apex and pale to medium reddish-orange below to about mid-point and burgundy-red in the bottom half; surface scruffy-punctate, especially in the bottom half, bluing when handled; basal mycelium white; the flesh is yellow, darker/richer that in the cap, with burdundy-red areas mostly in the bottom half and almost red in the base, staining blue erratically at the cap juncture and below, closer to the edge than cortex.
> Odor pleasant and fungal; taste is mild.
> Spore print is olive (brownish-green).
> Macrochemical Tests: KOH = amber brown in cap (pink area), medium muddy orange on cap flesh; NH4OH = pale dingy yellow on cap (pink area), grayish-blue (slate) on cap flesh.
> Spore measurements: [20/1/1], mounted in Melzer’s;
L x W = (8.4-)8.6~11.6 x (3.3-)3.5~4.0 μm; L x W = 10.0 × 3.7 μm;
Q = (2.18-)2.24~3.2; Q = 2.67; pale green and lacking oil droplets, fusiform in face-view (dorsal/ventral) and subtly inequilateral/subfusiform in side-view (dorsiventral) with a barely noticeable/practically nonexistent suprahilar plage.
Discussion: While not a dead ringer for the B. bicolor group gestalt, this mature mushroom has several morphological elements that hint at bicolor: the overall color scheme, the unstable cap pigment toward maturity, the yellow marshmallowy flesh, the spotty and erratic staining of the yellow flesh, and the spore size & shape. The fact that true bicolor has been observed growing in the immediate vicinity (obs 208545) also lends supporting evidence to bicolor connection. This collection has been marked for sequencing (nrLSU).

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 18-May-2018):
Results:
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of 914 bps was obtained from this collection. The sequence starts from the middle of the ITS4 primer and ends on the last character preceding the LR5 primer. There are 6 ambiguous characters, all are a “Y” (C/T).
> A BLASTn of this sequence indeed shows this collection to clade in Baorangia bicolor group of North America. The top hits are:
KF030246: Boletus bicolor var. bicolor voucher MB07-001 = 867/873 = 99.3% similar (the 6 mismatching bases are the ambiguities in MO288997)
KF030247: Boletus bicolor var. subreticulatus voucher 3818 = 863/870 = 99.2% similar (6 of 7 mismatching bases are the ambiguities in MO288997)
KF030249: Boletus subluridellus voucher 3737 = 871/880 = 99.0% similar (6 of 9 mismatching bases are the ambiguities in MO288997)
KF030248: Boletus rufomaculatus voucher 4414 = 869/880 = 98.8% similarity (6 of 11 mismatching bases are the ambiguities in MO288997)
KF030990: Boletus cf. bicolor 3921 = 855/869 = 98.4% similar (6 of 14 mismatching bases are the ambiguities in MO288997)
As a side note, I doubt that Dr. E. E. Both, the collector and identifier of voucher 3737, mistook B. bicolor for B. subluridellus – the latter being a distinct taxon in Neoboletus with red pores and a pale yellow stipe devoid of any red tones; in all likelihood, this is a “clerical” error made during the sample processing or tabulation of sequencing data for the Nuhn et al. (2013) paper.
Discussion:
The genetic data in conjunction with the aforementioned macro- and micro-morphological particulars of this collection firmly place it in the Baorangia bicolor group. Still overall it’s a morphological outlier that originally fooled me into thinking that it could be something else. Subjecting this collection to sequencing was very beneficial, all things considered.
It has been hypothesized in the Boletes of Eastern North America that B. bicolor could be a species complex. Even if this is true, nrLSU is hardly the locus to solve the puzzle. It remains to be seen if the “bicolor group” will stand up to a rigorous molecular scrutiny.

results.notes:
Same south-facing slope on my lawn where I have observed hundreds of examples of A. rooseveltensis over the past 15 years (10′ × 15′ area with some small oaks and a single old large shagbark hickory tree along a wood border).

This mushroom has basically the same color scheme as A. rooseveltensis, gray cap, white stipe, although with a very slightly olivaceous tone on the disc. White floccose deposits on stipe, long deep striations along the cap margin, white membranous volva that’s buried in the soil and breaks apart easily are all traits associated with rooseveltensis. This specimen is larger and more robust that most of the rooseveltensis I have observed in this spot. But, what really sets this one apart from the others is the size and shape of the spores, 11-16 × 7-12 with highly variable Q. Q’ appears to exceed 1.5.

Spored photographed from print collected on a slide. Two slightly different distances from the stipe represented, but in each case the spores fell from less than 1 cm from the cap margin. (Dimensions observed in photos need to be increased by ~17%.)

Several mysterious (to me anyway) specimens fruiting atop a fallen log in mixed hardwoods forest. Average size = 4 cm. long, 2 cm. wide, 1.1 cm high. Lumpy blackish-brown surface with fibrils that clump together when touched (may be due to moisture). Moist context has white and grayish concentric rings, visible when bisected. 3-4 angular pores/mm. Habitat: mixed hemlock and hardwood forest
Substrate: Moss at base of hemlock tree
Abundance: Few
Additional notes: ITS sequence is a 100% match with KX592722

On crumbling shale bedrock outcropping in a semi-arid grassland environment, along an ephemeral drainage. Full sun southwestern exposure.

Thallus yellow-brown, shiny, consisting of scattered or clumped areoles with 1 to many apothecia each. Algal layer in thallus is distinctly interrupted by hyphal bundles. Areoles are convex, becoming squamulose, with fissures and pits. Apothecia are sunken in areoles, with reddish coloration on rims, disks are dark red-brown, roughened. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium dingy, epihymenium brown. Spot tests are negative. However, a little K left on the slide from a previous specimen review resulted in yellow pigments diffusing into the surrounding water. C test was definitely negative, but the resulting KC was reddish from the contaminated slide.

Spores many per ascus, simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. 4-5 × 1.5-2.0µm.

I (Steve Roberts) found these at an inventory walk with Cumberland Mycological Society, growing on soil in mixed woods.

I immediately recognized this as a Gomphus, and with no reference materials handy, was thinking along the lines of Gomphus clavatus. Jay Justice, who was present immediately after the walk, looked at it and believed this might be Gomphus ludovicianus, a southern species from TX and LA named by Ron Petersen et. al. in 2014.

These specimens are being sequenced, so hopefully soon we will know for sure if this is G. ludoviacanus. The other possibility is G. clavatus, which is a western and northern species. Neither of these two purple Gomphus species has been recorded in the state of Tennessee to my knowledge.

I immediately recognized this as a Gomphus, and with no reference materials handy, was thinking along the lines of Gomphus clavatus. Jay Justice, who was present immediately after the walk, looked at it and believed this might be Gomphus ludovicianus, a southern species from TX and LA named by Ron Petersen et. al. in 2014.

The other possibility is G. clavatus, which is a western and northern species. Neither of these two purple Gomphus species have been recorded in the state of Tennessee to my knowledge.

results.notes:
A single fruitbody growing in rich humus over sand in pine & oak(?) woods across from 23 Laurel Ln 08088 (Tibbs Lake area).
The cap is 7.5 cm in diameter and its flesh is 0.8 cm thick in the middle; the gills are 6-7 mm wide; the curved stipe is ~8 cm long, 1.3 cm wide at the apex/juncture with the stipe, 1.1 cm wide at its narrowest point (~2 cm below the apex) and 2.5 cm wide max in the bulbous base. The appressed PV/annulus is positioned just below the mid-point of the stipe. The exposed flesh slowly turned pale pink around the stipe-cap junction, just above the gills and along the edges in the upper part of the stipe. The odor is sweet and pleasant, with a bitter chocolate note; no info on the taste. KOH on cap = negative. Spore measurements TBD.
The specimen was not saved on account of it being old and insect-damaged.

results.notes:
This impressively large and hefty, young solitary fruitbody was growing under pines and scrub oaks on the edge of woods along the south shoulder of Rt. 532 and ~30 yards from NGE. It was deeply inserted into the soil and the stipe bottom was brittle due to being waterlogged. Hence, I have likely broken off the bottom of the stipe during the laborious extraction; the soft, membranous volval sack got separated in the process, too, though I was able to recover most of it from the ground. Preserved for RET.
DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (posted 28-Jun-21):
> This collection was sampled for nrITS by Dr. Linas Kudzma. Unfortunately, the nrDNA tandem repeats in MO289538 apparently failed to homogenize in the ITS region. In other words, the “barcode gene” in this organism is represented by more than one ITS sequence. These ITS sequence variants are essentially identical, but vary in length because of insertion of 1 or more nucleotides at 3 different positions (=points of heterogeneity) in the locus. This resulted in raw sequence chromatograms that had to be worked on hard to get the most of out them because they show sequence mixtures. Fig. 1 illustrates what the forward read chromatogram looks like upon insertion of an extra base at position #120 in ITS1 in a population of nrDNA tandem repeats. The assigned base positions are correct and represent the major/shorter variant with 5 T’s in a row. The other variant has 6 T’s, so its peaks beyond that point are shifted over by one position, and the overlapping peaks thus follow a strict and recognizable pattern.
> Based on my thorough analysis of the raw chromatrograms, the uploaded full-length ITS sequence represents one of four sequence variants found in this organism. The haplotypes in the forward and reverse reads were resolved in converging direction beyond the first and last points of heterogeneity, respectively, and joined at the second (middle) point around character #438. In each resolution case, I proceeded with the major ITS variant (having taller peaks = larger area under peak). The reported sequence is the shortest one, 494 base pairs (bps).
> A BLASTn-100 of this sequence gave RET’s accession of Amanita williamsiae (MG982484) as the top hit at 99.03% similarity. The two sequence alignment is shown in Fig. 2. There are five mismatching positions; one of them is an ambiguity in both sequences. The other four are not directly associated with any of the noted points of heterogeneity. The base identities at those positions in my sequence are correct, so the observed differences are real.

results.notes: Cap broadly umbonate, 9 cm, yellow at the edges turning yellow-orange and then darkening to a brownish yellow at the center. Deeply striate over about 1/3 of cap. One white volval patch on the cap. Cap flesh cream, 2 mm thick where stipe meets the cap, thinning to almost nothing toward the edge. Gills free, close, pale yellow, 5 mm deep at most. Stipe pale yellow, fading to cream at the base, somewhat fibrous. 9 cm long by 9 mm thick at apex and 12 mm at base, with pale yellow annulus. Base surrounded by a robust cream-colored volva, which is attached only at the base of the stipe. Stipe flesh pale yellow, stuffed white. Growing singly under mixed oak, birch, white pine, hemlock.
This large cluster probably contained over 200 individual caps of all sizes.

results.notes: Sadly, I have no habitat data on this monstrosity. I found this specimen discarded in a grassy area along side a local neighborhood road. My thoughts are that one of the local tree companies (a few blocks away) grabbed it as a anomaly and tossed it out of the truck on the way back to the shop. What I do know for certain is that it is a white fleshed bolete with a strongly reticulated upper stipe, and a smooth lower stipe (possibly weakly reticulate). It grew with “it’s back against the wall” of something, my assumption is against a tree so I am going to assume it was mycorrhizal. There seems to be a darkish green dusting about the lower areas of the stipe, possibly spores but given the overall state of decomposition I am assuming that this is a mold growth. I currently am attempting to dry and save this specimen.

results.notes: This mushroom was growing in rich soil in a hole at the base of a tree. Although it was covered with black dirt, the color of the pileus was also a black or dark brown/grey color. This was a strange mushroom: it had some kind of yellow stuff over much of the surface, and had small yellow craters in the flesh of the pileus (see last picture). The mushroom was very dense.
